content: I, for one, applaud Mr. Obama's stance on this issue. While I support truth and transparency, the fact is that we have to draw the line as to where national interest outweighs the public's right (need) to know. OPSEC is always the priority. However, I'm not clear on just how much power he has in this matter, as the court has already ruled and demanded the release of the photos. Or am I incorrect in that understanding? It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
reply: I, for one, applaud Mr. Obama's stance on this issue. While I support truth and transparency, the fact is that we have to draw the line as to where national interest outweighs the public's right (need) to know. OPSEC is always the priority. However, I'm not clear on just how much power he has in this matter, as the court has already ruled and demanded the release of the photos. Or am I incorrect in that understanding? It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: hi carl I call it his war because he had the opportunity to end fighting in Iraq and Afganistan but did not. He ran on ending Iraq saying it was wrong and made a big stand on bringing the troops home. Only they are not coming home, they are going to Afganistan. Obama made it clear he was going to focus on Afganistan and Pakistan and just like the administration before him, made a promise to hunt down Bin Laden, the real terror behind 9/11. He can't go back later and put being in Afganistan on Bush. He has to own that as his own. Or he should have ended it along with Iraq don't you think? PS..it has always bothered me that in 8 years the Bush people could not get Bin Laden. Something is just not right about that. You can find Saddam in a hole in the desert but not Bin Laden in 8 years?

content: quote: Originally posted by FollowMeInfantry: I, for one, applaud Mr. Obama's stance on this issue. While I support truth and transparency, the fact is that we have to draw the line as to where national interest outweighs the public's right (need) to know. OPSEC is always the priority. However, I'm not clear on just how much power he has in this matter, as the court has already ruled and demanded the release of the photos. Or am I incorrect in that understanding? I believe you are correct regarding the courts. The CnC is not the final authority on this matter. I personally would prefer the photos were not released (at least while we have troops in-country). I do believe they should be sealed and safeguarded as evidence. I'd hate to see another blatant destruction of evidence like we did with the CIA interrogation videos.
quote: Originally posted by FollowMeInfantry: I, for one, applaud Mr. Obama's stance on this issue. While I support truth and transparency, the fact is that we have to draw the line as to where national interest outweighs the public's right (need) to know. OPSEC is always the priority. However, I'm not clear on just how much power he has in this matter, as the court has already ruled and demanded the release of the photos. Or am I incorrect in that understanding?
reply: I believe you are correct regarding the courts. The CnC is not the final authority on this matter. I personally would prefer the photos were not released (at least while we have troops in-country). I do believe they should be sealed and safeguarded as evidence. I'd hate to see another blatant destruction of evidence like we did with the CIA interrogation videos.
title: Obama opposes detainee abuse photo release

content: quote: you can't leave the war going there, send troops there,then if it gets ugly and I think it will, go back and blame it on the past administration as their war. a couple of points... 1. If I remember the wording correctly...He's said many times that Afganistan is a "just war". So he's not blaming anyone for going there. 2. he(obama) is responsable for what happens there NOW. But past actions(or inactions) can and do have a bearing on what happens there now. 3. when you said "if it gets ugly and I think it will, go back and blame it on the past administration as their war" you're predicting what you THINK will happen. Yes if it "gets ugly" and he blames that only on Bush then he'ld be wrong. But thats not whats happening here.

content: hi carl I call it his war because he had the opportunity to end fighting in Iraq and Afganistan but did not. He ran on ending Iraq saying it was wrong and made a big stand on bringing the troops home. Only they are not coming home, they are going to Afganistan. Obama made it clear he was going to focus on Afganistan and Pakistan and just like the administration before him, made a promise to hunt down Bin Laden, the real terror behind 9/11. He can't go back later and put being in Afganistan on Bush. He has to own that as his own. Or he should have ended it along with Iraq don't you think? PS..it has always bothered me that in 8 years the Bush people could not get Bin Laden. Something is just not right about that. You can find Saddam in a hole in the desert but not Bin Laden in 8 years?

content: quote: Originally posted by FollowMeInfantry: I, for one, applaud Mr. Obama's stance on this issue. While I support truth and transparency, the fact is that we have to draw the line as to where national interest outweighs the public's right (need) to know. OPSEC is always the priority. However, I'm not clear on just how much power he has in this matter, as the court has already ruled and demanded the release of the photos. Or am I incorrect in that understanding? I believe you are correct regarding the courts. The CnC is not the final authority on this matter. I personally would prefer the photos were not released (at least while we have troops in-country). I do believe they should be sealed and safeguarded as evidence. I'd hate to see another blatant destruction of evidence like we did with the CIA interrogation videos.
quote: Originally posted by FollowMeInfantry: I, for one, applaud Mr. Obama's stance on this issue. While I support truth and transparency, the fact is that we have to draw the line as to where national interest outweighs the public's right (need) to know. OPSEC is always the priority. However, I'm not clear on just how much power he has in this matter, as the court has already ruled and demanded the release of the photos. Or am I incorrect in that understanding?
reply: I believe you are correct regarding the courts. The CnC is not the final authority on this matter. I personally would prefer the photos were not released (at least while we have troops in-country). I do believe they should be sealed and safeguarded as evidence. I'd hate to see another blatant destruction of evidence like we did with the CIA interrogation videos.
title: Obama opposes detainee abuse photo release

content: quote: you can't leave the war going there, send troops there,then if it gets ugly and I think it will, go back and blame it on the past administration as their war. a couple of points... 1. If I remember the wording correctly...He's said many times that Afganistan is a "just war". So he's not blaming anyone for going there. 2. he(obama) is responsable for what happens there NOW. But past actions(or inactions) can and do have a bearing on what happens there now. 3. when you said "if it gets ugly and I think it will, go back and blame it on the past administration as their war" you're predicting what you THINK will happen. Yes if it "gets ugly" and he blames that only on Bush then he'ld be wrong. But thats not whats happening here.
